description: Change of use from Car Showroom (Use Class Sui Generis) to Retail Shop (Use Class A1)
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

Prior to the occupation of the retail unit (Use Class A1), a scheme for signage and markings in accordance with the paragraph 12 of the Transport Statement Addendum (dated May 2020)   and drawing number 195135/A/01 shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The agreed signage shall be installed and thereafter maintained. Reason: Insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate the proposed signage to be used at the site entrance. The submission and implementation of the measures would ensure that there are adequate entrance and exit arrangements to serve the development, and that the development accords with  Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions)  of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The  car parking spaces (including the disabled space) and parking layout as shown on drawing number 195135/A/01 Rev C shall be provided before the development to which it relates to is occupied,  and shall not thereafter be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it. Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy 6.13 of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The retail unit (Use Class A1) hereby approved shall not operate other than between the hours of 9.00am to 20.00pm Mondays to Sundays (including Bank or National Holidays).Reason: To safeguard the amenities of neighbouring properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions)  of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The servicing (including deliveries) of the retail unit (Use Class A1) hereby approved shall only be carried out in accordance with the Delivery and Servicing Plan (dated 20the May), and only take place between the hours of 07:00am to 19:00pm Monday to Saturday and between the hours of 09:00 to 17:00 on Sundays and Bank Holidays. Reason: To safeguard the amenities of neighbouring properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions)  of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

All vehicles (including delivery vehicles) shall be restricted to entering via the southern crossover and exiting via the northern crossover on a left-in and left-out basis in accordance with the Transport Statement Addendum (dated May 2020) and drawing number 195135/A/01 Rev B. Reason: In the interest of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions)  of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall be used for purposes falling within Use Class A1 (retail) only, and for no any other purpose as defined in the Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987 (as amended) or in any provision equivalent to that Class in any statutory instruction revoking and re-enacting that Order (with or without modification), without written consent from the Local Planning Authority first being obtained. Reason: To enable the Local Planning Authority to exercise control of the type of use within the category in order to safeguard the amenities of the area in accordance with Policies DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions)  and DM17 (Protecting Existing Employment Land and Premises) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey end of terrace dwelling. The site is located within Flood Risk Zone 3A (high probability). The site also falls within the designated Kingston Town Centre boundary, as well as an Area of Archaeological Significance.ProposalThe application seeks permission for the erection of a single-storey side and rear extension.Consultations10 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.Historic England: No consultation required.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The design of the proposed development;The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,The impact of the development on flood risk.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The proposed single storey side extension would infill the narrow area between the host building and boundary fencing of the property with a flat roof design and finished in materials to match the existing. Whilst the roof form and set back do not accord with the parameters of the Residential Design SPD, 2013 officers acknowledge the overall scale of the extension would be modest and would not be highly visible, given the the development's siting between the existing brick boundary fencing and Oaklea Passage. The application also proposes the construction of a single storey rear extension. This would measure a maximum of 3.6 metres from the existing rear wall of the dwellinghouse including a parapet wall (3m extension, 3.6 parapet wall) and beyond the parameters of the Residential Design SPD for single storey extensions. The proposed flat roof extension would have a parapet wall of approximately 3.3 m in height. Whilst not visible from the streetscene, the scale and depth of extension would not be characteristic of the established pattern of development to the rear of Oaklea Passage. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: The principal properties to consider in relation to amenity are Matham House which is a detached two storey property and separated by a brick boundary wall; and No.2 Oaklea Passage which has not been extended to the rear. Given the depth and siting along the shared boundary, the proposed single storey rear development would have an unacceptable adverse impact on outlook, and as properties along Oaklea Passage narrow to the rear along this terrace the proposed extension would also result in a sense of enclosure to the neighbouring property at No.2 Oaklea Passage.In addition, the applicant has failed to indicate that the proposed extension would not have an undue adverse impact on the light/sunlight and outlook on the nearest ground floor habitable room at No.2 Oaklea Passage. The proposed development would therefore have an unacceptable impact on the amenity of neighbouring properties. As stated above the application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 3A (high probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Officer Comment: The submitted flood risk form states that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate which is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).In conclusion, the proposed development would conflict with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

SiteThe application site is a two-storey end terrace dwellinghouse located on Archdale Place. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Relevant History19/00240/HOU - Conversion of garage into habitable room and erection of conservatory to the rear. Application Granted on 29 Mar 2019. With conditions.21/02732/HOU - Conversion of existing garage to habitable space with associated changes to fenestration and installation of 1no rooflight. Erection of single storey rear and side extensions.This most recent application was refused on the grounds that:The proposed conversion of the garage into a habitable room would have an unacceptable adverse impact on congestion and highway safety through the loss of off-street parking, thereby conflicting with Paragraph 111 of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), as well as Core Strategy Policy DM9 and Policy DM10 of the Councils LDF Core Strategy (2012).ConsultationsFour neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance; The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,The impact of the development on highways and transportation.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments:  The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officers Comments: The proposal involves the conversion of an existing garage into a habitable room, as previously refused. Officers note that properties on Archdale Place benefit from either an integral garage, or a designated parking space. The proposed development in this case would involve the removal of the only parking space designated for the application site, i.e. it does not benefit from any alternative off-site parking bay. The highway in front of the application site is used to access allocated parking spaces for other residential units on Archdale Place and therefore parking on the road outside the application property would not be supported. Furthermore, there is limited on street parking availability in the immediate vicinity. Since the previous refusal, the applicant has failed to submit any details as to how car parking provision for the application site would be accommodated. Therefore, the proposed conversion of a garage in this case is considered to have an unacceptable adverse impact on congestion and highway safety, through the loss of designated off-street parking. In conclusion, the proposed development would conflict with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling on the northern side of Mount Pleasant Road.9x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The front wall of the proposed porch extension, would be located 1.0 metre forward of the existing front wall of the host property. However, the proposed porch would reflect the character of the main house, would have a symmetrical appearance when viewed alongside the existing porch extension at no.49 Mount Pleasant Road and not appear to be an incongruous addition, when viewed from Mount Pleasant Road. The proposed porch would appear subordinate and proportionate. While the single storey rear extension would not strictly adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD 2013, in terms of a maximum depth of 4.0 metres, officers note that the proposed rear extension otherwise meets Kingston Council design standards.The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Officers note that the proposed rear extension would be a maximum height of 3.6 metres, where it meets with the existing house. In addition to the flank wall of the rear extension would be set away from the neighbouring property at no.45 Mount Pleasant Road. The single storey rear extension would have a maximum depth of 4.0 metres. However, the proposed rear extension, would replace a smaller existing rear extension and there is an existing rear extension at no.49 Mount Pleasant Road. It is therefore considered that the proposed development would not additionally affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy, significantly enough to warrant refusal. The proposed porch, to the front of the dwelling, would also not significantly affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a two-storey, semi-detached dwelling located on the south-eastern side of Orme Road, which is a well-established residential area. There is an existing side extension to the neighbouring property at No. 8 Orme Road. There are no windows within the side elevation of this neighbouring extension, which face the application property. The building line of the application property is set marginally further forward than this neighbour. To the front of the property is a driveway that provides off-street parking. The property is not listed nor is it within a conservation area and there are no other historic assets in the vicinity. At the rear, there is a single storey extension that spans the full width of the property. The property is within Flood Risk Zone 1 (low probability), as defined by the Environment Agency, and is within a locally designated Critical Drainage Area.Planning History20/02394/HOU- Erection of two storey side extension. REFUSED 08.03.2021.15x neighbouring properties were notified of the application and no representations have been received following the consultation period. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and- - The impact of the development on the highways and transport.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposal includes the retention of a detached garage building to the rear of the property. The proposal would involve the erection of a single-storey side extension. The roof aspect of the proposal would project across the front elevation to provide a canopy/porch to the front entrance door and join up with the two-storey bay window aspect of the front elevation.The Residential Design Guide advises that single storey side extensions should reflect and relate well to the main house and its roof form, and the height of the roof should never encroach on the sill of windows of the second storey. Single storey side extensions should normally be set-back from the front wall of the original house by at least 500mm. However, officers stated in the delegated report for the previous planning refusal (20/02394/HOU) for this site, that for the ground floor element of the proposal, the:- "front elevation, would meet the Design Guide's requirements for a front extension, in that it would not project beyond the existing bay window and there would also be separation distance between the two features."The Residential Design Guide also advises that single storey side extensions should be set in from the shared side boundary, by at least 250mm, so guttering does not overhang adjoining land. The Agent for the current application has stated that the flank wall of the proposal would only be set in 100mm from the shared side boundary with no.8 Orme Road. However, a parapet gutter would be installed above the outer flank wall of the proposal and the existing side extension at no.8, is built up to the common shared boundary, with the host property.The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed extension would increase the footprint of the property to the side. However, it is considered that the remaining space would be adequate for residents to enjoy without having their amenity compromised. There are no windows within the side elevation of the neighbour at No. 8 Orme Road that would be affected by the erection of side ground floor extension. The neighbour at No. 8 Orme Road has erected a single storey side extension that is used as a bedroom and is flush with the front elevation of their property.The proposed extension would project beyond the front building line of No. 8 Orme Road. The windows within the neighbouring extension are off-set from the boundary. The application property is located to the south-east of No. 8 Orme Road. There would be a slight loss of daylight caused to No. 8 Orme Road, as a result of the proposed extension. However, the loss of daylight caused to No. 8 Orme Road, would not be significant enough to warrant refusal. The forward projection of the proposed extension would not result in a poor outlook for the neighbour due to the extent of the forward projection and the positioning of the neighbouring windows.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety.  Policy DM10 supports this stance. Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3, ensuring that a minimum of two short-stay and two long-stay cycle parking spaces are provided.Officers acknowledge that the proposals would result in the loss of access to the existing garage directly from the front of the property. However, the hardstanding to the front of the property would be of sufficient size to accommodate one vehicle in accordance with the standards set out in the London Plan. Whilst the side access providing access to the rear garden would be lost as a result of the proposals the retention of the detached garage would provide adequate storage space for bicycles. As such, there is no objection to the proposals in this regard.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (
